ygData.subject: Re: Plastic synapse traits applied to neurons?

Hi Tomoljack, yes you are right I put traits inside both nodes and 
links i=
n the NEAT code that I distributed.  Note that that code was 
written and d=
istributed before I actually did the adapative work.  
At the time, my inte=
ntion was simply to keep all possible options 
open.  It is true that Hebbi=
an learning does not require a special 
function at the neuron, but some ot=
her kinds of learning *could*, 
such as classic sensitization where an inco=
ming connection to a 
neuron becomes more sensitive because of a level of a=
ctivity on 
another incoming connection.  The traits are really meant to be=
 
generic parameter holders for any arbitrary function to be possible 
to p=
arameterize in the future, for nodes or connections.  

You may want to che=
ck out the leakyNEAT.zip files in the Files 
section of this group, and als=
o my own NEATadaptcore.tar code.  The 
NEATadaptcore contains the actual co=
de for making hebbian updates on 
connections based on trait parameters, so=
 that will answer your 
questions on how it actually works.  The leakyNEAT =
is interesting 
because it adds a time constant parameter to each node, so =
it's an 
example of how nodes might have their own independent parameters, =

though I am not certain the author (Tyler Streeter) actually used 
traits =
to add that parameter.

By the way, there will soon be a new release of NEA=
T in the form of 
rtNEAT (but which works as normal NEAT as well) with a lo=
t of this 
stuff built in (i.e. the adaptation code).  The trait code will =
also 
be cleaner and work better in this new release.

ken

--- In neat@yah=
oogroups.com, "tomoljack" <thomasjack@g...> wrote:
>
> Investigating the C+=
+ source, it seems like NNodes are assigned
> Traits. I've read "EVOLVING A=
DAPTIVE NEURAL NETWORKS WITH AND 
WITHOUT
> ADAPTIVE SYNAPSES", but I can't=
 find anything about neurons having
> traits, only connection genes. Is thi=
s something standard 
in "Hebbian
> learning", so that it wasn't mentioned =
in that publication?
> 
> The adjustment in weight is a function of the act=
ivities of the
> incoming and outgoing neuron. How could this be applied to=
 a 
neuron?
> 
> Also, when the learning equation refers to the "activities=
" of the
> incoming and outgoing neurons, does it mean the sum of the input=
s 
to
> those neurons, or the outputs of those neurons?
>
